title: I want to say that computers are now everywhere. Can I say 'the ubiquity of computers'? - Quora

response.answer_text: You can. It is grammatically correct, but it is a awkward, and as written it is a sentence fragment. You would need to complete the sentence by explaining what it is about their ubiquity. “With the ubiquity of computers, they are now in every home and office.” That is wordy. It would be better to write “Computers are ubiquitous. They are in every home and office.” That makes it a a complete sentence. It would be even better to write, “Computers are now in every home and office.”. Your goal in writing should be clarity. You should be writing so that others grasp your meaning easily. Sometimes using a word like ubiquitous confuses the meaning and makes it seem that you’re trying too hard to sound academic. That can backfire.

You would say “Computers are ubiquitous” to get across what you say you want to get across. The phrase “the ubiquity of computers” would be equivalent to the phrase “the fact that computers are now everywhere”.
